trans-unit.source: This is a new service. Your feedback will help us improve it

Call us on 0300 303 0655 and quote your reference number
Our privacy policy for video hearings
The video hearings service is managed by HM Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS).
When you use this service we (HMCTS) will ask you to provide some personal data. This privacy policy explains why we collect your personal data, what we do with it, and your rights.
Why we collect your personal data
We collect your personal data so you can take part in a video hearing and to meet legal requirements. We also collect data to improve the service.
What we do with your data
Your personal data is processed by our staff in the UK, and the data is stored within the EEA.

HMCTS is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice. The Ministry of Justice is known as the âdata controllerâ of the personal data you provide. The Ministryâs personal information charter explains more about how we process data.
The personal data we collect includes:
your name, address and contact details, including your email address and telephone number
details of your company and your role, if applicable
details of anyone who acts on your behalf or anyone that you act for in a video hearing
information we gather to assess your suitability for a video hearing
information that tells us if you open an email from us, or click on a link in an email
the login details you use to access the video hearings service
information about how you use this service, like your IP address and the web browser you use. We do this by using cookies.
How long we keep your data

The video hearings service will keep this information for 3 months after the date your hearing is booked to take place. We will then delete it. Information about your application or your case is held by a different department in HMCTS and different arrangements may apply.
Storing and sharing your data internationally
Sometimes we need to send your personal information outside of the UK. When we do this we comply with data protection law.
to see the personal data that we hold on you
to have the personal data corrected
to have the personal data removed or deleted (this will depend on the circumstances, for example if you decide not to continue your claim or application)
that access to the personal data is restricted (for example, you can ask to have your data stored for longer and not automatically deleted)
If you want to see the personal data that we hold on you, you can:
complete a form to make a
Your request goes to the MoJ as data controller
write to us: Disclosure Team, Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
You can ask for more information about:
agreements we have on sharing information with other organisations
when we are allowed to pass on personal information without telling you
our instructions to staff on how to collect, use or delete your personal information
how we check that the information we hold is accurate and up-to-date
You can contact the MoJ data protection officer, by:
writing to us: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
if you want to complain about how we've handled your personal data.
You can also complain to the
if youâre not satisfied with our response or believe we are not processing your personal data lawfully.
If you typed the web address, check it is correct.
If you pasted the web address, check you copied the entire address.
If the web address is correct or you selected a link or button, contact us using the options below.
This guide explains how video hearings work and provides information you might need to participate.
You are not authorised to use this service
It looks like you are not registered for this service.
If you think this is a mistake and you need to speak to someone, please contact us using the options below.
Court hearings like yours can take place in a court building or by video.
all participants gather in the courtroom in front of the judge.
all participants, including the judge, take part from different locations using a computer. They can see and hear each other throughout the hearing.
The court will decide if it's more suitable for the hearing to take place in a court building or by video.
We need to ask you some questions to help the court decide.
Before you answer the questions, we'll show you what the different types of hearing are like.
Hearings held in a court or tribunal building
The short video on the next screen explains how hearings are conducted in a court or tribunal building.
See what it's like to be in a video hearing
The video on the next screen shows you what it would be like to take part in a hearing from your computer.
Switch on your camera to see the short interactive video.
'Why do I need to use my camera?'
Your camera is now switched on
You're now ready to watch the interactive video.
When the video has ended, show the judge's view to see how you will appear to others in the hearing.
When the video has ended, click 'Continue'. You can try the practice video hearing again if you like.
Help the court decide on a suitable method for your hearing
We now need to ask you some questions to help the court decide which method will be suitable for your hearing.
You've blocked your camera and microphone
We're sorry, you can't go any further without using your camera and microphone.
Please call us now or send a message if you need help to change your computer settings.
